Question.p: Write down whether or not each of the following is a discrete random variable.
Give a reason for your answer.
a The average lifetime of a battery.
b The number of days in a week.
c The number of moves it takes to complete a game of chess.

Solution.p: i) This is not a discrete random variable. Time is a continuous variable.
ii) This is not a discrete random variable. It is always 7, so does not vary
iii) This is a discrete random variable. It is always a whole number but it does vary.

Question.p: A fair die is thrown four times and the number of times it falls with a 6 on the top, Y, is noted. Write down all the possible values of y.

A bag contains two discs with the number 2 on them and two discs with the number 3 on them. A disc is drawn at random from the bag and the number noted. The disc is returned to the bag. A second disc is then drawn from the bag and the number noted.
a Write down the sample space.
The discrete random variable X is the sum of the two numbers.
b Write down the probability distribution for X.
c Write down the probability function for X.

x1234

where k is a constant.

Solution.p: Using the fact that the probabilities add up to 1:

Find

A discrete random variable X has a probability distribution

a Draw up a table to show the cumulative distribution function F(x).
b Write down F(5).c Write down F(2.2).
A discrete random variable has a cumulative distribution function F(x) given in the table.

a Draw up a table to show the probability distribution X.
b Write down P(X < 5).c Find P(2 ≤ X < 5).

5 The random variable X has a probability function
P(X=x)={ kxx=1,3,5k(x−1)x=2,4,6
where k is a constant.
a Find the value of k.
b Draw a table giving the probability distribution of X.
c Find P(2 ≤ X < 5).
d Find F(4).
e Find F(1.6).

Solution.p: d Remember F means the cumulative function
(This could also be done by adding P(1) P(2) P(3) and P(4).)
e 1.6 lies below 2 but above 1. Because this is a discrete random variable F(1.6) is the same as F(1) which is 118

Question.p:
The discrete random variable X has the probability function
P(X=x)={ 0.1x=−2,−1αx=0,10.3x=2
a Find the value of α
b Draw a table giving the probability distribution of X.
c Write down the value of F(0.3).

The discrete random variable X has a cumulative distribution function F(x) defined by
F(x)={ 0x=01+x6x=1,2,3,4,51x>5
a Find P(X ≤ 4).
b Show that P(X = 4) is 16.
c Find the probability distribution for X.
The discrete random variable X has a cumulative distribution function F(x) defined by F(x)={ 0x=0(x+k)216x=1,2 and 31x>3
a Find the value of k.
b Find the probability distribution for X.
Find E(X) and E(X2) for the following distributions of x.
A biased die has the probability distribution
Find E(X) and E(X2).
The random variable X has a probability function
a Construct a table giving the probability distribution of X.
b Work out E(X) and E(X2).
c State with a reason whether or not (E(X))2 = E(X2).
Two coins are tossed 50 times. The number of heads is noted each time.
a Construct a probability distribution table for the number of heads when the two coins are tossed once, assuming that the two coins are unbiased.
b Work out how many times you would expect to get 0, 1 or 2 heads.
The following table shows the actual results.
c State whether or not the actual frequencies obtained support the statement that the coins are unbiased. Give a reason for your answer.

Solution.p: We would expect to get 1 head 25 times and 0 or 2 heads 12.5 times each.
c The coins would appear to be biased. There were far too many times when 2 heads appeared and not enough when 0 heads appeared.

Question.p: The random variable X has the following probability distribution.
Given E(X) = 2.9 find the value of a and the value of b.

Solution.p: The probabilities add up to 1 so

Question.p: A fair spinner with equal sections numbered 1 to 5 is thrown 500 times. Work out how many times it can be expected to land on 3.

Solution.p: We can expect it to land on 3 100 times.

Question.p:
For the following probability distribution
x−10123
P(X = x)1515151515
a write down E(X).
b find Var(X).
Find the expectation and variance of each of the following distributions of X.
Given that Y is the score when a single unbiased die is rolled, find E(Y) and Var(Y).
Two fair cubical dice are rolled and S is the sum of their scores.
a Find the distribution of S.
b Find E(S).
c Find Var(S).
Two fair tetrahedral (four-sided) dice are rolled and D is the difference between their scores.
a Find the distribution of D and show that P(D=3)=18.
b Find E(D).
c Find Var(D).

Solution.p: From Distribution Table it can be seen that P(D=3)=18

Question.p: A fair coin is tossed repeatedly until a head appears or three tosses have been made. The random variable T represents the number of tosses of the coin.

a Show that the distribution of T is
t123
P(T = t)121414
b Find the expectation and variance of T.

The random variable X has the following distribution:
x123
P(X = x)aba
where a and b are constants.
a Write down E(X).
b Given that Var(X) = 0.75, find the values of a and b.
Find
a E(2X),
b Var (2X).

Solution.p: Remember mean is E(X) and variance is Var X.

Question.p: E(X) = 2, Var(X) = 6
Find
a E(3X),
e Var (3X),
f Var (3X + 1),
g Var (X − 1).
The random variable X has an expectation of 3 and a variance of 9.
Find
c Var(2X + 1),
d Var(2 + X).
The random variable X has a mean μ and standard deviation σ.
Find, in terms of μ and σ
a E(4X),
d Var(2X + 2),
e Var(2X − 2).

Solution.p: d Var(2X + 2) = 22 Var(X) = 4σ2 (Remember Standard deviation is σ so variance is σ2)

Find:
c Var(3Y + 1),
d Var(2 − 3Y),
e E(Y2),
The random variable T has a mean of 20 and a standard deviation of 5.
It is required to scale T by using the transformation S = 3T + 4.
Find E(S) and Var(S).
A fair spinner is made from the disc in the diagram and the random variable X represents the number it lands on after being spun.
a Write down the distribution of X.
b Work out E(X).
c Find Var(X).
d Find E(2X + 1).
e Find Var(3X − 1).

The discrete variable X has the probability distribution
x−1012
P(X = x)0.20.50.20.1
a Find E(X),
b Find Var (X),
c Find E(13X+1),
d Find Var(13X+1).
X is a discrete uniform distribution over the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. Work out the expectation and variance of X.
Seven similar balls are placed in a bag. The balls have the numbers 1 to 7 on them. A ball is drawn out of the bag. The variable X represents the number on the ball.
a Find E(X).
b Work out Var(X).
A fair die is thrown once and the random variable X represents the value on the upper face.
a Find the expectation and variance of X.
b Calculate the probability that X is within one standard deviation of the expectation.
A card is selected at random from a pack of cards containing the even numbers 2, 4, 6, …, 20. The variable X represents the number on the card.
a Find P(X > 15).
b Find the expectation and variance of X.

Solution.p: a This is a uniform distribution.
b Let R be a uniform distribution over the numbers 1,2, … 10.

Question.p: A card is selected at random from a pack of cards containing the odd numbers 1, 3, 5, …, 19. The variable X represents the number on the card.
a Find P(X > 15).
b Find the expectation and variance of X.

Solution.p: b Y = X − 1 (X as in previous question)

Question.p: A straight line is drawn on a piece of paper. The line is divided into four equal lengths and the segments are marked 1, 2, 3 and 4. In a party game a person is blindfolded and asked to mark a point on the line and the number of the segment is recorded. A discrete uniform distribution over the set (1, 2, 3, 4) is suggested as model for this distribution. Comment on this suggestion.

Solution.p: A discrete uniform distribution is not likely to be a good model for this distribution. The game depends on the skill of the player. The points are quite likely to cluster around the middle.

Question.p: In a fairground game the spinner shown is used.
It cost 5p to have a go on the spinner.
The spinner is spun and the number of pence shown is returned to the contestant.
If X is the number which comes up on the next spin,
a name a suitable model for X,
b find E(X),
c find Var(X),
d explain why you should not expect to make money at this game if you have a large number of goes.

Solution.p: d The expected winnings are less than the 5p stake.
